subsections.title: Success Criteria (Precipitation)
points: Explain forms of precipitation.
Explain how precipitation is formed.

subsections.title: Definition of Precipitation
subsections.content: Precipitation is a form of water (liquid or solid) falling from the atmosphere.

subsections.title: Forms of Precipitation
points: Rain – Liquid water falling from the sky. Most common form.
Sleet – Frozen raindrops that refreeze while falling.
Snow – Ice crystals formed in clouds and fall as snowflakes.
Hail – Solid balls of ice formed in cumulonimbus clouds during thunderstorms.
Drizzles – Light showers or small droplets of water.
Dew – Moisture that condenses near the Earth's surface, especially in the morning.

subsections.title: Necessary Conditions for Precipitation Formation
points: Presence of water vapour in the air.
Presence of condensation nuclei (e.g., dust, smoke) in the air.
Warm moist air must rise into the atmosphere.
Low temperature (dew point) must be reached for condensation.
Cloud droplets must grow large and heavy enough to fall.

subsections.title: Success Criteria (Rainfall)
points: Explain the formation of different types of rainfall.
Identify areas in the world receiving different types of rainfall.
Interpret rainfall data from various sources.

subsections.title: Definition of Rainfall
subsections.content: Rainfall is liquid water falling from the atmosphere.

subsections.title: Necessary Conditions for Rain Formation
points: Warm moist air must rise by evaporation, air mass convergence, or mountain uplift.
Wind must carry moisture into the atmosphere.
Air must cool in the atmosphere to allow condensation.
Dust, smoke, or pollen must be present to aid condensation.
High temperatures help initiate evaporation from Earth’s surface.

subsections.title: Types of Rainfall
subsections.content: There are three main types of rainfall:
points: Relief rainfall
Convectional rainfall
Frontal (Cyclonic) rainfall

subsections.title: Relief Rainfall
subsections.content: Formed when moist air is forced to rise over mountains.
points: Occurs on windward side where rain-bearing wind hits the mountain.
Leeward side (rain shadow) gets little or no rain, e.g. Chikwawa and Nsanje behind Mulanje.
Found in Malawi’s highlands: Mulanje, Shire Highlands, Dedza, Nyika, Viphya Plateaus.
Widespread, falls for long hours, more on windward side.

subsections.title: Convectional Rainfall
subsections.content: Formed by the sun heating Earth’s surface causing evaporation and rising air.
points: Air rises, cools, and condenses to form cumulonimbus clouds.
Falls in the afternoon with thunderstorms and lightning.
Heavy but short-lived (20 minutes to an hour).
Localized – small area coverage.
Occurs mostly in summer.

subsections.title: Frontal Rainfall
subsections.content: Also called cyclonic rainfall; formed when warm air rises over cold air at a front.
points: Warm air condenses to form clouds and rain.
Light showers falling for long hours.
Extensive cloud cover with storms but no lightning.
Covers a large area and can fall at any time of day.

subsections.title: Similarities among Rainfall Types
subsections.content: Despite different causes, they share some similarities:
points: All involve rising warm moist air.
Air cools to dew point where condensation occurs.
Clouds form and further cooling leads to rainfall.

subsections.title: Differences among Rainfall Types
points: Convectional – air rises due to heating and evaporation.
Relief – air rises due to mountain barriers.
Frontal – warm air rises over a cold air mass.

subsections.title: Interpreting Rainfall Data
points: Rainfall data is collected at weather stations.
Presented using isopluvial maps, tables, and graphs.
Isopluvial maps use colours and lines (isohyets) to show rainfall patterns.
Data analysis involves calculating mean and total annual rainfall.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Weather is the condition of the atmosphere at a specific time and place, while climate is the long-term average of weather patterns.
points: Weather can change daily; climate changes slowly over decades.
Climate affects agriculture, water supply, and lifestyle.

subsections.title: Elements of Weather
subsections.content: Main atmospheric conditions measured to determine weather.
points: Temperature, rainfall, wind speed and direction, humidity, air pressure.

subsections.title: Climate Zones
subsections.content: Climate zones classify regions based on long-term weather patterns.
points: Tropical: hot and wet.
Temperate: moderate temperatures.
Polar: cold throughout the year.

subsections.title: Measuring Weather
subsections.content: Various instruments are used to observe and record weather conditions.
points: Thermometer – measures temperature.
Barometer – measures air pressure.
Rain gauge – measures rainfall.
Anemometer – measures wind speed.
Hygrometer – measures humidity.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Natural disasters are extreme, sudden events caused by environmental factors.
points: They pose risks to life, property, and the environment.
Often occur without warning and can be devastating.

subsections.title: Common Types
subsections.content: Several types of natural disasters affect different regions of the world.
points: Earthquakes – sudden shaking of the Earth's surface.
Floods – overflow of water onto land.
Drought – prolonged period of low rainfall.
Volcanic eruptions – magma and gases expelled from Earth's crust.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Maps are symbolic representations of the Earth's surface used to show geographical features.
points: They help us locate places, measure distances, and understand terrain.

subsections.title: Basic Elements of a Map
subsections.content: Essential features that make maps readable.
points: Title – tells what the map shows.
Scale – represents the ratio of map distance to real distance.
Legend/Key – explains symbols used.
Compass rose – shows direction (N, E, S, W).

subsections.title: Types of Maps
points: Topographic – shows elevation and landscape.
Political – shows countries, cities, and boundaries.
Thematic – focuses on specific themes like population or climate.

subsections.title: Map Reading Techniques
subsections.content: Skills required to understand and interpret maps.
points: Use of grid references (e.g., 3A, 5D).
Contour lines – show elevation and shape of the land.
Measuring distances using the map scale.
